questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with an acute onset of weakness in her left hand that started 6 hours ago. She has not had numbness or tingling of the hand. Other than recent episodes of blurry vision and headaches, her medical history is unremarkable. She has one daughter who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis at age 23. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 144/84 mm Hg. Examination shows facial erythema. There are mild scratch marks on her arms and torso. Left hand strength is slightly decreased and there is mild dysmetria of the left hand on finger-to-nose testing. The remainder of the neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Her laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
55%


Leukocyte count
14500/mm3


Segmented neutrophils
61%


Eosinophils
3%


Lymphocytes
29%


Monocytes
7%


Platelet count
690,000/mm3


Her erythropoietin levels are decreased. CT scan of the head without contrast shows two focal areas of hypo-attenuation in the right frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to prevent complications of this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy can be considered to prepare a patient for a stem cell transplant. Stem cell transplantation is the only curative treatment for myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), which is a possible late-stage complication of PV. However, contrary to PV, in which all three cell lines are increased, MDS is characterized by a reduction in one or more cell lines, i.e., erythrocytopenia, leukocytopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is the first-line treatment for an acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis (MS). The vision impairment seen in this patient is highly typical for MS and is often the first manifestation. However, the patient is past the typical age of onset for MS (20–40 years). In addition, she does not have any other findings typical for MS such as internuclear ophthalmoplegia or signs of spinal cord demyelination (e.g., spasticity, hyperreflexia, loss of vibration sense).

C) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant with three main indications: venous thrombosis, post-myocardial infarction prevention of ischemic events, and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Even though this patient did have an ischemic stroke, there are no signs of atrial fibrillation. Therefore, she should receive antiplatelet therapy for long-term prevention of further cerebrovascular events, but not warfarin.

D) INCORRECT:

Imatinib is a first-line treatment for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). In the accelerated phase, CML can result in extreme pleocytosis with subsequent infarctions, which would explain this patient's neurological symptoms. However, decreased rather than increased RBCs, WBCs and platelets would be expected in the accelerated phase of CML.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with PV are at high risk of developing thrombotic complications such as stroke, myocardial infarction, and deep vein thrombosis due to increased cell count (e.g., evidenced by increased hematocrit) and subsequent hyperviscosity of the blood. To reduce the red blood cell mass and thus the risk for thrombotic complications, phlebotomy (250–500 mL) should be performed every 2–3 days until a hematocrit of ≤ 45% is established. Contraindications to repeated phlebotomies include anemia, hypotension, dehydration, and infection. Thrombocytosis is less affected by phlebotomy because platelets have a significantly shorter lifespan and regeneration period. Therefore, all patients with PV should receive antiplatelet prophylaxis with aspirin unless contraindications are present.

If first-line treatment (i.e., phlebotomy and aspirin) is ineffective or poorly tolerated, or if the patient has a high risk of thrombosis (e.g., > 60 years of age, history of thrombosis), cytoreductive therapy with hydroxyurea or interferon alpha is recommended. Ruxolitinib is used for patients resistant or intolerant to hydroxyurea.

F) INCORRECT:

Although interferon alpha can be used to treat PV, it is only a second-line agent. There are not enough randomized controlled trials to conclude that interferon alpha is superior to the current first-line treatment in terms of safety and efficacy.
questions.hint: This patient's sudden hand weakness in conjunction with her CT findings is suggestive of stroke. Considering her facial erythema, scratch marks, history of blurry vision and headaches, and her laboratory values (elevated erythrocyte, granulocyte, and platelet counts), polycythemia vera (PV) is the most likely cause.

questions.text:
Two hours after a 2280-g (5-lb) male newborn is born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old primigravid woman, he has 2 episodes of vomiting and jitteriness. The mother has noticed that the baby is not feeding adequately. She received adequate prenatal care and admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes daily while pregnant. The newborn's temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 171/min and respirations are 60/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows facial plethora. Capillary refill time is 3 seconds. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
70%


Leukocyte count
7800/mm3 



Platelet count
220,000/mm3 



Serum



 Glucose
42 mg/dL


 Calcium
8.3 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a common, self-resolving condition that results from excess fluid in the lungs. It classically occurs in full-term neonates born by cesarean delivery and resolves within 4 hours. This patient was not born by cesarean delivery, and transient tachypnea of the newborn would not explain his laboratory abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

While intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is a potential complication in the newborn, it most commonly occurs in infants with low birth weight (< 1500 g) or premature infants (< 32 weeks' gestation). While IVH can cause irregular respirations, this patient does not have any other symptoms to suggest IVH, including lethargy, hypotonia, irregular eye movements, seizures, or bulging anterior fontanelle. Also, IVH is not consistent with this patient's laboratory abnormalities, especially elevated hemoglobin levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is the result of a deficiency in pulmonary surfactant within the immature lungs of a premature infant. NRDS classically manifests immediately after birth in premature infants with tachypnea, nasal flaring, intercostal retractions, and/or expiratory grunting. While this patient has developed some symptoms of respiratory distress, this occurred in the first 2 hours after delivery. Furthermore, he was not born prematurely and thus, is unlikely to have NRDS.

D) INCORRECT:

Neonatal hyperinsulinism is a possible complication in infants born to mothers with diabetes. Exposure to maternal hyperglycemia causes excess insulin production by the fetal pancreas. Neonatal hyperinsulinism can cause hypoglycemia, which may manifest with jitteriness, poor feeding, respiratory distress, and neonatal polycythemia. However, this patient's mother does not have a history of diabetes mellitus, making hyperinsulinism unlikely. This newborn's hypoglycemia is likely due to polycythemia (from increased glucose uptake by circulating RBCs), which is caused by a different condition.

E) INCORRECT:

While infants of diabetic mothers may have cardiac abnormalities, this patient has no murmur to suggest congenital heart disease. Additionally, while cyanotic heart defects may cause symptoms of respiratory distress in the newborn, it would be less likely to explain this patient's laboratory abnormalities.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's neonatal polycythemia is most likely due to intrauterine hypoxia. The hypoxic state leads to increased erythropoiesis, which boosts the production of RBCs to facilitate tissue oxygenation. At birth, newborns typically present with elevated venous hematocrit (> 65%), respiratory distress, cyanosis, apnea, poor feeding, hypoglycemia (due to increased glucose uptake by the circulating RBCs), and plethora. Further manifestations may include lethargy, irritability, jitteriness, seizures, and vomiting. Risk factors for developing neonatal polycythemia include maternal tobacco use, maternal diabetes, small or large size for gestational age, and delayed umbilical cord clamping.
questions.hint: This newborn's elevated venous hematocrit (> 65%) indicates neonatal polycythemia.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, increased sweating, and itching in his legs for the past 2 years. He has chronic bronchitis. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 24 years and drinks one to two beers every night. His only medication is a tiotropium bromide inhaler. His vital signs are within normal limits. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 116 kg (256 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Physical examination shows facial flushing and bluish discoloration of the lips. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Erythrocyte count
6.9 million/mm3


Hemoglobin
20 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
91 μm3



Leukocyte count
13,000/mm3


Platelet count
540,000/mm3


Serum



Ferritin
8 ng/mL


Iron
48 μg/dL


Total iron-binding capacity
400 μg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Weight loss can be beneficial for various conditions including obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OSA may cause obesity, tiredness, and increased RBC count due to elevated EPO secretion (secondary to chronic hypoxia). However, a history of restless sleep and irregular snoring with apneic episodes would be expected in patients with OSA. Also, increased EPO levels would not explain this patient's leukocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation is the treatment of choice in individuals with iron deficiency anemia. Patients typically present with fatigue, decreased serum ferritin and serum iron, as well as elevated or high-normal total iron binding capacity. However, iron deficiency typically leads to microcytic anemia (hypochromic) and decreased hemoglobin, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib is the first-line treatment in leukemias associated with Philadelphia translocation, which includes > 90% of cases of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Common features of CML include fatigue, increased sweating, and leukocytosis. Pruritus and plethora are not typical of CML. Also, affected individuals often have a much higher leukocyte count compared to this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is a potentially curative treatment option for various hematologic conditions, including chronic myeloid leukemia, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and myelofibrosis. This patient most likely suffers from PV, which is an incurable disorder. The primary goal in disease management involves controlling RBC mass and reducing the risk of thrombotic complications.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is the first-line treatment for sickle cell disease. Hydroxyurea can also be used as an adjunct cytoreductive treatment for PV in patients with a high risk for thrombosis (e.g., > 60 years of age, history of thrombosis) or for whom first-line treatment of PV is ineffective or poorly tolerated. None of these indications are observed in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids, e.g., budesonide, belong to the first-line treatment for patients with COPD. Chronic hypoxia in individuals with COPD may lead to increased secretion of EPO, resulting in elevated production of erythrocytes (secondary erythrocytosis). Although COPD is associated with increased EPO levels, this alone would not explain the leukocytosis seen in this patient.

G) CORRECT:

PV is an incurable disease; the primary goal of treatment is to reduce RBC mass and thus the risk of thrombotic complications. First-line treatment of PV consists of periodic phlebotomy, which reduces cell counts and hyperviscosity. In addition, antiplatelet prophylaxis with aspirin should be administered unless contraindications are present because platelets have a significantly shorter lifespan and regeneration period and are therefore less affected by phlebotomy. If first-line treatment is ineffective or poorly tolerated, or if the patient has a high risk of thrombosis (e.g., > 60 years of age, history of thrombosis), cytoreductive therapy with hydroxyurea or interferon alpha is recommended. Ruxolitinib is used for patients resistant or intolerant to hydroxyurea.

Diagnosis of PV can be established if a patient meets all three major diagnostic criteria (i.e., evidence of increased RBCs, bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth, and evidence of a JAK2 gene mutation) or the first two major criteria and the minor criterion (i.e., decreased EPO levels).
questions.hint: This patient presents with constitutional symptoms (fatigue, sweating), pruritus, and plethora (i.e., facial flushing and cyanotic lips). In combination with an increase of all three blood cell lines (i.e., erythrocytosis, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis), these findings suggest polycythemia vera (PV). In patients with PV, low serum iron and serum ferritin, as well as high-normal total iron-binding capacity indicate increased incorporation of iron into hemoglobin due to excessive hematopoiesis and hemoglobin production.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of blurry vision, headache, and multiple episodes of nosebleeds over the last few weeks. She reports that she has also been itching a lot, especially after getting ready for work in the mornings. She has had an 8-kg (17.6-lb) weight loss and increasing fatigue during the past 6 months. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 158/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no lesions or evidence of trauma in the nasal cavity. Her face, palms, nail beds, oral mucosa, and conjunctiva appear red. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin concentration is 19 g/dL, hematocrit is 58%, platelets are 450,000/μL, and erythropoietin level is below normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stress erythrocytosis (Gaisbock syndrome) is a form of secondary erythrocytosis characterized by an increase in RBC mass due to a decrease in plasma volume (relative polycythemia). The condition can manifest with typical findings of PV, including a (relative) increase of RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), hypertension, plethora, neurological symptoms, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, this condition typically occurs in obese middle-aged men receiving diuretic treatment, which is not the case for this patient. Moreover, stress erythrocytosis would not explain this patient's splenomegaly, elevated platelet count, and low EPO levels.

B) CORRECT:

A mutation in the Janus kinase 2 gene (JAK2 gene) is an important etiological factor in a number of myeloproliferative neoplasms. The mutation is present in almost all cases of PV and in ∼ 50% of patients with essential thrombocythemia and primary myelofibrosis. For the diagnosis of PV to be established, all three major criteria or the minor criterion plus two major criteria must be fulfilled. The major criteria are evidence of increased RBCs (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth, and genetic analysis showing a mutation in the JAK2 gene. The minor criterion is decreased EPO levels.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), including hypertension with facial flushing, mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes. However, increased ICP would not explain this patient's highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, or weight loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of predominantly megakaryocyte lineage is a typical finding in patients with essential thrombocythemia (ET). This patient has some features of ET, including elevated platelet count, mucosal bleeding, headache, visual disturbances, weight loss, and fatigue. However, ET would not explain her highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct) and plethora. Moreover, in patients with ET, pruritus that is exacerbated by presumably hot water is relatively uncommon, occurring in less than 5% of cases.

E) INCORRECT:

An EPO receptor mutation is a typical finding in individuals with primary familial and congenital polycythemia (PFCP). PFCP is a rare disorder that may manifest with findings similar to those seen in PV, including highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), low EPO levels, plethora, fatigue, headache, hypertension, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, a patient with PFCP would typically have a normal-sized spleen, earlier onset of symptoms, and a family history positive for this condition. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical findings of PFCP, such as a normal platelet count, which indicates that other hematopoietic cell lines are not involved (isolated erythrocytosis).

F) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can cause paraneoplastic syndrome, in which increased EPO production results in an inappropriate absolute polycythemia. Individuals with RCC may present with findings similar to those seen in this patient, including elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), elevated platelet count, weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome, pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, and plethora. However, this patient presents with low EPO levels, making paraneoplastic syndrome unlikely. Moreover, she lacks other typical features of RCC, including hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass.
questions.hint: This patient has a highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb and ↑ Hct), low EPO levels, and thrombocytosis along with constitutional symptoms (weight loss, fatigue), hyperviscosity syndrome (triad of mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes), pruritus (likely exacerbated by hot water when getting ready for work), hypertension, splenomegaly, and plethora. These are features of polycythemia vera (PV).

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive headache, dizziness, and weakness. Hot showers cause generalized pruritus. He had a normal routine health examination 5 years ago, at which point routine laboratory studies were also normal. His pulse is 90/min and blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows facial plethora. Examination of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The spleen is palpable 2 cm below the left costal margin. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the JAK2 gene. Which of the following sets of findings is most likely in this patient?



EPO levels
Plasma volume
RBC mass
SaO2



A
normal
decreased
normal
normal


B
increased
normal
increased
decreased


C
decreased
increased
increased
normal


D
decreased
normal
normal
normal


E
increased
normal
increased
normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This combination can be found in relative polycythemia. Stress erythrocytosis (Gaisbock syndrome) and severe dehydration may lead to a decrease in plasma volume, causing a relative increase in RBC count (including ↑ Hb, ↑ hematocrit). Relative polycythemia can manifest with typical findings of PV, including hypertension, plethora, headache, dizziness, and weakness. However, relative polycythemia would neither explain the splenomegaly nor the JAK2 gene mutation in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination can be found in secondary polycythemia due to hypoxia (↓ SaO2). Conditions associated with increased stimulation of erythropoiesis due to reduced oxygen saturation cause increased secretion of EPO (↑ EPO) and an appropriate (physiological) increase in RBC mass (physiologically appropriate secondary polycythemia). Physiologically appropriate secondary polycythemia can manifest with clinical findings similar to those seen here. However, there is no cause of hypoxia in this patient's history (e.g., high-altitude exposure, chronic pulmonary or cardiac disease). Moreover, the JAK2 gene mutation in this patient makes a different diagnosis more likely.

C) CORRECT:

In almost all patients with PV, a mutation in the JAK2 gene leads to uncontrolled, EPO-independent proliferation of the myeloid cell lines, resulting in increased blood cell mass. Increased red blood cell mass suppresses secretion of EPO by the kidneys, resulting in low EPO levels, which is an important diagnostic marker of the disease. Individuals with PV usually have normal arterial O2 saturation (SaO2) and a normal or slightly increased plasma volume. Normal SaO2 helps to distinguish PV from types of secondary polycythemia caused by chronic hypoxia (see “Causes of polycythemia” table).

Treatment of choice is periodic phlebotomy, which reduces cell counts and hyperviscosity. In addition, antiplatelet prophylaxis with aspirin as well as cytoreductive therapy with hydroxyurea, interferon alpha, or ruxolitinib may be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

This combination may be found in essential thrombocythemia (ET), which is associated with low EPO levels in approx. 50% of patients. This patient has some features of ET, including headache, fatigue, dizziness, splenomegaly, and a JAK2 gene mutation (which occurs in ∼ 50% of cases). However, ET does not cause an increase in RBC mass, so plethora is not a typical finding. Moreover, pruritus exacerbated by hot water is uncommon (< 5% of cases). A different diagnosis is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

This combination can be found in secondary polycythemia due to a non-physiological elevation of EPO levels. Conditions associated with autonomous production of EPO (e.g., certain renal diseases like renal cell carcinoma), as well as exogenous EPO intake (e.g., EPO doping) result in highly elevated EPO levels, which may lead to a non-physiological increase in RBC mass, causing physiologically inappropriate secondary polycythemia. Individuals with physiologically inappropriate secondary polycythemia can present with clinical findings similar to those seen here. However, this patient lacks other features of an underlying disease (e.g., hematuria in the case of renal cell carcinoma). Moreover, the JAK2 gene mutation in this patient makes a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Aquagenic pruritus, nonspecific neurological symptoms, plethora, hypertension, and splenomegaly in conjunction with a mutation in the JAK2 gene are highly suggestive of polycythemia vera (PV).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of worsening pain and swelling in both of his hands for 1 week. He appears distressed. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F). Examination shows erythema, swelling, warmth, and tenderness on the dorsum of his hands. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.1 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear is shown. The drug indicated to prevent recurrence of this patient's symptoms is also used to treat which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The first-line treatment for primary syphilis is penicillin, not hydroxyurea. Penicillin is also used for prophylaxis of infection with encapsulated organisms in patients with (functional) asplenia. On blood smear, (functional) asplenia manifests as target cells and/or Howell-Jolly bodies, not sickle cells. While this patient with sickle cell disease is at risk of functional asplenia and should therefore be treated with penicillin until at least the age of five, penicillin is not indicated to prevent recurrence of vaso-occlusive crisis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Hypochromic erythrocytes with a dark central area, a pale ring surrounding the center, and a dark outer rim can be seen (dashed red circles on overlay). Due to this “bullseye” appearance on light microscopy, they are called target cells. On electron microscopy, they would appear bell-shaped (overlay illustration; visual axis in light microscopy depicted in red).

The finding of target cells is nonspecific and may indicate various hemoglobinopathies, such as thalassemia, liver disease, or asplenia.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment of chronic kidney disease (CKD) includes a salt- and protein-restricted diet as well as dialysis and treatment of associated complications such as hypertension (ACE inhibitor or ARB), hyperlipidemia (statins), diabetes mellitus (insulin), bleeding (desmopressin) or anemia (erythropoietin). In CKD, a blood smear may show echinocytes. Treatment of CKD does not include hydroxyurea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; medium power magnification)

There is a mixture of normal erythrocytes, with a uniform, smooth, and rounded surface (blue dashed circles), and erythrocytes, with numerous, evenly spaced, thorny projections (blue circles). These cells are referred to as echinocytes or burr cells.

Echinocytes can occur as a result of oxidative or colloid osmotic stress. They may also be an artifact resulting from prolonged storage of blood samples.

C) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia that commonly occurs in patients with vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency. Due to inhibition of DNA synthesis blood cell precursors arrest in the G2 cell phase and continue to grow, resulting in megaloblasts. However, blood smear would show macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, not sickle cells. Moreover, therapy would include supplementation of folate or vitamin B12, not hydroxyurea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear

Throughout the specimen, there are cells with an irregular, oval form and marked hyperchromasia (intense staining) that are known as macrocytes (examples indicated by arrows). These are surrounded by normal erythrocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).

Macrocytes may be found in megaloblastic forms of anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron intoxication is especially common in pediatric care (ingestion of red iron tablets mistaken for candy). An iron overload can also be caused by β-thalassemia (major), which can present with severe anemia already in infancy. Insufficient erythropoiesis can lead to extramedullary hematopoiesis as well as bone marrow hyperplasia. However, blood smear would show dacrocytes and/or target cells, not sickle cells. Treatment of either iron intoxication or β-thalassemia would involve deferoxamine, but not hydroxyurea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Erythrocytes with a teardrop shape can be seen throughout the image (red overlay). The majority of the erythrocytes appear round and normal.

Teardrop-shaped erythrocytes, known as dacrocytes, are found in conditions that involve extramedullary hematopoiesis (e.g., myelofibrosis, thalassemia, splenomegaly).

E) CORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is the first-line treatment for frequent, acute episodes of pain or other vaso-occlusive events as well as severe symptomatic anemia due to sickle cell crisis. Hydroxyurea increases fetal hemoglobin by an unknown mechanism, thus reducing HbS proportionally and decreasing RBC polymerization (HbF does not polymerize). It is also used in the treatment of polycythemia vera and other myeloproliferative disorders. In these conditions, hydroxyurea is beneficial because of its myelosuppressive effects, which are a result of its inhibition of ribonucleoside diphosphate reductase.

F) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a rare acquired hemolytic anemia caused by the destruction of erythrocytes by complement. Treatment includes eculizumab, a monoclonal recombinant antibody that inhibits the immune system by binding to and deactivating complement C5, but not hydroxyurea. Eculizumab is also used to treat some forms of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), but this patient has no symptoms of HUS and a blood smear of a patient with HUS would show schistocytes, not sickle cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; high magnification)

Normal erythrocytes (example indicated by arrow; bottom left) and several fragmented erythrocytes (schistocytes; examples indicated by black dashed circles) with a normal convex side (example marked with red line) and a fragmented side that is concave or straight (example marked with blue line) can be seen. Additionally, multiple erythrocytes with dark staining Howell-Jolly bodies (examples indicated by arrowheads) are present.

Schistocytes are a diagnostic finding in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias. These cellular fragments can also result from mechanical damage to erythrocytes (e.g., due to prosthetic heart valves). Howell-Jolly bodies can occur in functional asplenia or after splenectomy, severe anemia, and bone marrow disorders (e.g., myelodysplastic syndrome).
questions.hint: Given the presence of sickle cells on peripheral blood smear, this patient is likely suffering from a vaso-occlusive episode of dactylitis (hand-foot syndrome) due to sickle cell disease (SCD). Hydroxyurea is a medication that is often used in SCD patients to prevent recurrence of these episodes.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to a physician for a routine health maintenance examination. One week ago, she moved to the mountains in Denver after living in New York City all her life. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely on analysis of a blood sample obtained now compared to prior to her move?



Erythropoietin level
O2 saturation
Plasma volume



A
↓
unchanged
↑


B
Unchanged
↓
unchanged


C
Unchanged
unchanged
↓


D
↑
unchanged
unchanged


E
↑
↓
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of decreased EPO levels, normal oxygen saturation, and increased plasma volume can be seen in patients with primary polycythemia, a condition resulting from congenital (i.e., primary familial and congenital polycythemia) or acquired (e.g., polycythemia vera) bone marrow defects. This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of decreased blood oxygen saturation with normal EPO levels and plasma volume can be seen in CO poisoning and any acute pulmonary process causing hypoxia (e.g., pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, pulmonary edema). This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of reduced plasma volume with normal EPO and oxygen saturation levels can be seen in relative polycythemia, which is characterized by an increase in erythrocyte count secondary to fluid loss (e.g., due to diarrhea). This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of increased EPO levels with normal oxygen saturation and plasma volume can be seen in physiologically inappropriate secondary polycythemia, in which autonomous production of EPO (e.g., by renal cell carcinoma) leads to an increased erythrocyte count. This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

E) CORRECT:

The partial pressure of oxygen decreases as altitude increases, reducing pulmonary gas exchange. Therefore, this patient's recent move from New York to Denver likely caused decreased O2 saturation and mild hypoxemia. In response to hypoxemia, EPO levels rise, which increases hematocrit and improves the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. In addition, plasma volume falls rapidly in the first few days at high altitude due to decreased renal bicarbonate and water reabsorption compensating for respiratory alkalosis, as well as a fluid shift from the intravascular to the intracellular and interstitial space. This combination of changes is referred to as physiologically appropriate secondary polycythemia. (See “Causes of polycythemia” table.)

Over a prolonged stay at high altitude, EPO levels will stay slightly elevated, whereas plasma volume will slowly return to normal.
questions.hint: New York City is located at sea level, while Denver is known as the “mile-high city” (1,610 meters above sea level). Barometric pressure decreases with elevation, reducing the partial pressure of oxygen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of fatigue and blurry vision. He also reports that he has had an unintentional 4.5 kg (10 lb) weight loss during the past 6 months. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 17.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 88 μm3, and increased red cell volume. Serum erythropoietin concentration is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polycythemia vera (PV) is caused by a mutation in the JAK2 gene that leads to uncontrolled, EPO-independent proliferation of the myeloid cell lines, resulting in increased RBC mass. Individuals with PV usually have normal arterial O2 saturation (SaO2) and a slightly increased or normal plasma volume. The increased RBC mass suppresses secretion of EPO by the kidneys, causing EPO levels to decrease, not increase.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) involves impaired alveolar gas exchange secondary to destruction of the alveolar walls (emphysema), which causes hypoxia with a decreased arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2). Hypoxia leads to increased erythropoietin (EPO) secretion from the kidneys. Increased EPO levels stimulate erythropoiesis, which results in an appropriate (physiological) increase in RBC mass (appropriate absolute polycythemia), while plasma volume remains unchanged. This patient's normal SaO2 is not consistent with appropriate absolute polycythemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive diuretic use can lead to severe dehydration and a decrease in plasma volume while regular erythropoietin (EPO) levels and arterial oxygen saturation are maintained. The loss of plasma volume can lead to a relative increase in RBC mass, i.e., relative polycythemia. This patient's normal plasma volume and increased EPO levels are not consistent with relative polycythemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) results in the excessive proliferation of the myeloid blood cell line, particularly granulocytes. Patients in the accelerated phase of CML most commonly present with erythrocytopenia and anemia, which is due to suppression of erythropoiesis by uncontrolled proliferation of the myeloid lineage. Increased RBC mass and EPO levels would not be expected in a patient with CML.

E) CORRECT:

Increased erythropoietin (EPO) levels and RBC mass (red cell volume) with a normal plasma volume and arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2) are consistent with secondary polycythemia due to autonomous EPO production or exogenous EPO intake (e.g., EPO doping). Increased EPO levels induce erythropoiesis, causing an increase in RBC mass (inappropriate absolute polycythemia) without affecting SaO2 or plasma volume. Hepatocellular carcinoma is a known cause of autonomous EPO production. Other causes of inappropriate absolute polycythemia include renal cell carcinoma, polycystic kidney disease, pheochromocytoma, and hemangioblastoma.

See "Causes of polycythemia" table.
questions.hint: An increased RBC mass and erythropoietin level in the presence of normal oxygen saturation suggest inappropriate absolute polycythemia.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive headache and dizziness for the past 3 months. During this time, she has also noticed generalized itching when taking a bath. Her pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows facial flushing. The tip of the spleen is palpable 2 cm below the left costal margin. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient?



Erythropoietin level
Plasma volume
RBC mass
SaO2




A
Normal
decreased
normal
normal


B
Decreased
increased
increased
normal


C
Increased
normal
increased
decreased


D
Increased
normal
increased
normal


E
Decreased
normal
normal
normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased plasma volume and a normal EPO level, RBC mass, and SaO2 are consistent with relative polycythemia caused by severe dehydration. Severe dehydration may lead to a decrease in plasma volume, causing a relative increase in RBC count (including ↑ Hb, ↑ hematocrit). Relative polycythemia can also present with headache, dizziness, and weakness. However, relative polycythemia would not explain this patient's splenomegaly.

B) CORRECT:

This patient likely has polycythemia vera (PV), which is caused by a mutation in the JAK2 gene, leading to uncontrolled, EPO-independent proliferation of the myeloid cell lines, resulting in increased RBC mass. The increased RBC mass suppresses the secretion of EPO by the kidneys, causing decreased EPO levels. Individuals with PV usually have normal arterial O2 saturation (SaO2) and a slightly increased or normal plasma volume. Normal SaO2 helps to distinguish PV from types of secondary polycythemia caused by chronic hypoxia.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased EPO level and RBC mass, normal plasma volume, and decreased SaO2 are consistent with secondary polycythemia due to hypoxia (↓ SaO2). Conditions associated with increased stimulation of erythropoiesis due to reduced oxygen saturation cause increased secretion of EPO (↑ EPO) and an appropriate (physiological) increase in RBC mass (appropriate absolute polycythemia). Appropriate absolute polycythemia can present with clinical findings similar to those seen here. However, there is no cause of hypoxia in this patient's history (e.g., high-altitude exposure, chronic pulmonary or cardiac disease).

D) INCORRECT:

An increased EPO level and RBC mass with a normal plasma volume and SaO2 are consistent with secondary polycythemia due to autonomous production of EPO (e.g., renal cell carcinoma) or exogenous EPO intake (e.g., EPO doping). Increased EPO levels cause an increase in RBC mass (inappropriate absolute polycythemia) without affecting SaO2 or plasma volume. Clinical findings include headache, dizziness, and hypertension, and, in very severe cases, aquagenic pruritus, splenomegaly, and facial plethora. However, this patient neither has a history of exogenous EPO intake nor other features of an underlying disease (e.g., hematuria in the case of RCC).

E) INCORRECT:

A decreased EPO level with normal plasma volume, RBC mass, and SaO2 is consistent with essential thrombocythemia (ET). This patient has some features of ET, including headache, fatigue, dizziness, and splenomegaly. However, this condition does not cause an increase in RBC mass. Plethora is therefore not a typical finding in patients with ET. Moreover, in individuals with ET, pruritus exacerbated by hot water, as seen in this patient, is rather uncommon (< 5% of cases).
questions.hint: This patient's clinical findings (headache, dizziness, aquagenic pruritus, hypertension, splenomegaly, and facial plethora) should raise concern for a condition that can be treated with periodic phlebotomy.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman reports a one-month history of dizziness, headaches, and paresthesias in her hands. She has hypertension but no other comorbidities and has never smoked.
On examination, her heart rate is 75 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 162/85 mm Hg, her oxygen saturation is 98% while she is breathing ambient air, and her BMI is 22. Her lungs are clear on auscultation. An abdominal examination reveals splenomegaly, and examination of the hands reveals erythema.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
14,500
4500–11,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
76.6
80–100



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
17.9
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
58.5
36.0–46.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
475,000
150,000–350,000


Similar results are seen on repeat blood tests over the next 4 weeks. The serum erythropoietin level is low.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to establish the cause of this patient’s elevated hemoglobin level?

choices.text: Serum iron level and total iron-binding capacity
Peripheral blood screening for mutations in JAK2

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires all three major criteria or the two first major criteria plus the minor criterion. A bone-marrow biopsy can be helpful when there is diagnostic uncertainty, for example with milder degrees of erythrocytosis or if no JAK2 mutations are found in the peripheral blood. In addition, the presence of myelofibrosis on bone-marrow biopsy provides prognostic information.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum levels of iron and ferritin are typically low in patients with polycythemia vera, but these tests would not be helpful in confirming the diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has polycythemia vera (PV), given the very elevated hemoglobin level in combination with the low erythropoietin level. PV is an acquired myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an increased erythrocyte mass. The World Health Organization criteria for diagnosis (updated in 2016) are as follows:

Major Criteria:

1 Elevated hemoglobin level (>16.0 g/dL in women; >16.5 g/dL in men), elevated hematocrit (>48% in women; >49% in men), or elevated red-cell mass

2 Bone-marrow biopsy consistent with PV

3 Presence of the JAK2 V617F or another similar JAK2 mutation

Minor Criterion:

1 Serum erythropoietin level below the normal reference range

Diagnosis of PV requires all three major criteria or the two first major criteria plus the minor criterion. Of note, patients with sustained erythrocytosis (women with hemoglobin levels >16.5 g/dL or hematocrit >49.5%; men with hemoglobin levels >18.5 g/dL or hematocrit >55.5%) do not need a bone-marrow biopsy for the diagnosis of PV if they have both a JAK2 mutation and a subnormal serum erythropoietin level. This patient may fall into this category — if she has a JAK2 mutation, then she would fulfill all the criteria for PV and would not need invasive testing such as bone-marrow biopsy. A bone-marrow biopsy can be helpful when there is diagnostic uncertainty, for example with milder degrees of erythrocytosis or if no JAK2 mutations are found in the peripheral blood. In addition, the presence of myelofibrosis on bone-marrow biopsy provides prognostic information. More than 95% of patients with PV and 50% to 60% of patients with essential thrombocythemia and primary myelofibrosis carry the JAK2 V617F mutation.

Key learning point: An elevated hemoglobin value (>16.0 g/dL in a woman or >16.5 g/dL in a man) in a patient with a low erythropoietin level and the JAK2 V617F gene mutation is indicative of the diagnosis of polycythemia vera.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum levels of iron and ferritin are typically low in patients with polycythemia vera, but these tests would not be helpful in confirming the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring red-cell mass requires an isotope study and is not routinely performed in patients with erythrocytosis.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man reports episodic burning and erythema in his hands for the past several weeks. The episodes, which last from minutes to several hours and are not prompted by cold temperature, have been increasing in frequency for 2 weeks. The patient also reports epigastric pain, headache, fatigue, and diffuse pruritus. He used to drink one or two beers per day, but he stopped because alcohol consumption sometimes triggered an episode. He quit smoking 8 years ago.
On examination, the patient has a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 127/78 mm Hg, and a BMI of 22. He has notable facial plethora. His spleen is palpated 4 cm below the left costal margin. He has no hepatomegaly or palpable lymphadenopathy.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
20.7
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)
59.4
41.0–53.0


Leukocytes (per mm3)
14,300
4500–11,000


Platelets (per mm3)
787,000
150,000–350,000


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
77
80–100


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.9
0.3–1.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.1
0.8–1.3



Serum erythropoietin (IU/liter)
2
5–36


Iron (μg/dL)
10
50–150


Ferritin (ng/mL)
4.0
30–300


Transferrin saturation (%)
3
15–45


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Essential thrombocythemia, another myeloproliferative neoplasm, is characterized by excessive production of platelets in the absence of increased red-cell mass. It is diagnosed only when a patient does not meet criteria for other MPNs or secondary causes of thrombocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal-cell carcinoma, obstructive sleep apnea, and carbon monoxide exposure are all causes of secondary polycythemia and are typically associated with an elevated, not a low, serum erythropoietin level.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal-cell carcinoma, obstructive sleep apnea, and carbon monoxide exposure are all causes of secondary polycythemia and are typically associated with an elevated, not a low, serum erythropoietin level.

D) CORRECT:

Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) characterized by increased red-cell mass, elevated hemoglobin, erythromelalgia (red, hot, painful extremities), pruritus, and a low serum erythropoietin level. More than 95% of patients with polycythemia vera harbor the JAK2 V617F mutation.

An increased hemoglobin level does not always imply increased red-cell mass. Spurious polycythemia, typically in the context of low plasma volume, can produce high hemoglobin levels in the absence of hematologic disease. Measurement of red-cell mass is performed using radioisotopes and is not frequently undertaken. The diagnosis of polycythemia vera relies on assessment of erythropoietin levels and detection of the JAK2 mutation.

Key learning point: A patient with erythromelalgia, an elevated hemoglobin level, and a low serum erythropoietin level is likely to have polycythemia vera.
Image Description:

The left upper extremity and both feet appear erythematous and swollen.

The appearance was accompanied by increased skin temperature and burning pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal-cell carcinoma, obstructive sleep apnea, and carbon monoxide exposure are all causes of secondary polycythemia and are typically associated with an elevated, not a low, serum erythropoietin level.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of fatigue, increased sweating, and itching in his legs for the past 2 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 116 kg (256 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Physical examination shows facial flushing and bluish discoloration of the lips. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Erythrocyte count
6.9 million/mm3


Hemoglobin
20 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,000/mm3


Platelet count
540,000/mm3


Serum



Ferritin
8 ng/mL


Iron
48 μg/dL


Total iron-binding capacity
400 μg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Weight loss can be beneficial for various conditions including obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OSA may cause obesity, tiredness, and increased RBC count due to elevated EPO secretion (secondary to chronic hypoxia). However, a history of restless sleep and irregular snoring with apneic episodes would be expected in patients with OSA. Also, increased EPO levels would not explain this patient's leukocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation is the treatment of choice in individuals with iron deficiency anemia. Patients typically present with fatigue, decreased serum ferritin and serum iron, as well as elevated or high-normal total iron binding capacity. However, iron deficiency typically leads to microcytic anemia (hypochromic) and decreased hemoglobin, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib is the first-line treatment in leukemias associated with Philadelphia translocation, which includes > 90% of cases of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Common features of CML include fatigue, increased sweating, and leukocytosis. Pruritus and plethora are not typical of CML. Also, affected individuals often have a much higher leukocyte count compared to this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is the first-line treatment for sickle cell disease. Hydroxyurea can also be used as an adjunct cytoreductive treatment for PV in patients with a high risk for thrombosis (e.g., > 60 years of age, history of thrombosis) or for whom first-line treatment of PV is ineffective or poorly tolerated. None of these indications are observed in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

PV is an incurable disease; the primary goal of treatment is to reduce RBC mass and thus the risk of thrombotic complications. First-line treatment of PV consists of periodic phlebotomy, which reduces cell counts and hyperviscosity. In addition, antiplatelet prophylaxis with aspirin should be administered unless contraindications are present because platelets have a significantly shorter lifespan and regeneration period and are therefore less affected by phlebotomy. If first-line treatment is ineffective or poorly tolerated, or if the patient has a high risk of thrombosis (e.g., > 60 years of age, history of thrombosis), cytoreductive therapy with hydroxyurea or interferon alpha is recommended. Ruxolitinib is used for patients resistant or intolerant to hydroxyurea.

Diagnosis of PV can be established if a patient meets all three major diagnostic criteria (i.e., evidence of increased RBCs, bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth, and evidence of a JAK2 gene mutation) or the first two major criteria and the minor criterion (i.e., decreased EPO levels).
questions.hint: This patient presents with constitutional symptoms (fatigue, sweating), pruritus, and plethora (i.e., facial flushing and cyanotic lips). In combination with an increase of all three blood cell lines (i.e., erythrocytosis, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis), these findings suggest polycythemia vera (PV). In patients with PV, low serum iron and serum ferritin, as well as high-normal total iron-binding capacity indicate increased incorporation of iron into hemoglobin due to excessive hematopoiesis and hemoglobin production.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of blurry vision, headache, and multiple episodes of nosebleeds over the last few weeks. She reports that she has also been itching a lot. She has had an 8-kg (17.6-lb) weight loss and increasing fatigue during the past 6 months. Her blood pressure is 158/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no lesions or evidence of trauma in the nasal cavity. Her face, palms, nail beds, oral mucosa, and conjunctiva appear red. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin concentration is 19 g/dL, hematocrit is 58%, platelets are 450,000/μL, and erythropoietin level is below normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A mutation in the Janus kinase 2 gene (JAK2 gene) is an important etiological factor in a number of myeloproliferative neoplasms. The mutation is present in almost all cases of PV and in ∼ 50% of patients with essential thrombocythemia and primary myelofibrosis. For the diagnosis of PV to be established, all three major criteria or the minor criterion plus two major criteria must be fulfilled. The major criteria are evidence of increased RBCs (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth, and genetic analysis showing a mutation in the JAK2 gene. The minor criterion is decreased EPO levels.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), including hypertension with facial flushing, mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes. However, increased ICP would not explain this patient's highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, or weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of predominantly megakaryocyte lineage is a typical finding in patients with essential thrombocythemia (ET). This patient has some features of ET, including elevated platelet count, mucosal bleeding, headache, visual disturbances, weight loss, and fatigue. However, ET would not explain her highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct) and plethora. Moreover, in patients with ET, pruritus that is exacerbated by presumably hot water is relatively uncommon, occurring in less than 5% of cases.

D) INCORRECT:

An EPO receptor mutation is a typical finding in individuals with primary familial and congenital polycythemia (PFCP). PFCP is a rare disorder that may manifest with findings similar to those seen in PV, including highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), low EPO levels, plethora, fatigue, headache, hypertension, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, a patient with PFCP would typically have a normal-sized spleen, earlier onset of symptoms, and a family history positive for this condition. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical findings of PFCP, such as a normal platelet count, which indicates that other hematopoietic cell lines are not involved (isolated erythrocytosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can cause paraneoplastic syndrome, in which increased EPO production results in an inappropriate absolute polycythemia. Individuals with RCC may present with findings similar to those seen in this patient, including elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), elevated platelet count, weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome, pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, and plethora. However, this patient presents with low EPO levels, making paraneoplastic syndrome unlikely. Moreover, she lacks other typical features of RCC, including hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass.
questions.hint: This patient has a highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb and ↑ Hct), low EPO levels, and thrombocytosis along with constitutional symptoms (weight loss, fatigue), hyperviscosity syndrome (triad of mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes), pruritus (likely exacerbated by hot water when getting ready for work), hypertension, splenomegaly, and plethora. These are features of polycythemia vera (PV).

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with six months of headaches, fatigue, and occasional dizziness to the clinic. He reports generalized itching after hot showers and increased facial flushing over the past three weeks. He does not smoke and denies living at high altitude. Physical examination shows a ruddy complexion and mild splenomegaly. Chest imaging is normal, and renal ultrasound shows no evidence of masses (see lab results).

Oxygen saturation
98%



Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
184 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


Hematocrit
0.56
0.42 - 0.52


RBC mass
Elevated by 20%
Normal


Serum erythropoietin level
Below normal
4.3 - 29 mIU/mL



Which of the following diagnoses best explains this patient’s findings?

choices.text: Subclinical cardiopulmonary disease causing chronic hypoxia
Ectopic erythropoietin secretion by a renal malignancy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital high-affinity hemoglobin variants cause elevated red blood cell mass due to a left-shifted oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, typically resulting in increased erythropoietin secretion. The low erythropoietin level in this patient is inconsistent with this condition. Additionally, the clinical features and age suggest a primary process rather than a congenital condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic hypoxia from cardiopulmonary disease typically leads to secondary polycythemia with increased erythropoietin levels. The patient's normal oxygen saturation and chest imaging, along with a low erythropoietin level, make this unlikely. The clinical features align more with a myeloproliferative process.

C) CORRECT:

Polycythemia rubra vera is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by unregulated red blood cell production independent of erythropoietin. The elevated hemoglobin, hematocrit, and red blood cell mass, along with a low serum erythropoietin level, suggest an intrinsic clonal process. Clinical features such as aquagenic pruritus, facial flushing, and splenomegaly further support this diagnosis. Most cases involve mutations in the Janus kinase 2 (JAK2) gene, leading to constitutive activation of the JAK-STAT pathway and uncontrolled erythroid proliferation.

Key learning point: Polycythemia rubra vera is characterized by elevated red blood cell mass, low serum erythropoietin levels, and often splenomegaly, distinguishing it from secondary causes of polycythemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic erythropoietin production by renal malignancy usually results in elevated erythropoietin levels. The absence of a renal mass on ultrasound and the low erythropoietin level do not support this diagnosis. The symptom profile is more characteristic of a primary hematologic process.

questions.text:
You are caring for a male newborn, born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old primigravid woman. Two hours after birth, he has had 2 episodes of vomiting and is jittery. His mother reports that he is not feeding well. She received adequate prenatal care and smoked one pack of cigarettes daily during pregnancy. The newborn weighs 2280 g. His temperature is 36.3°C, pulse is 171/min, and respirations are 60/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. On examination, he has facial plethora and a capillary refill time of 3 seconds. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit (Hct), blood

0.70 L/L (0.38–0.50)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
7.8 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
220 × 109/L (130–380)


Glucose, blood
2.3 mmol/L (4.0–6.0)


Calcium (Ca), total, blood
2.08 mmol/L (2.12–2.52)


Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is the result of a deficiency in pulmonary surfactant within the immature lungs of a premature infant. NRDS classically manifests immediately after birth in premature infants with tachypnea, nasal flaring, intercostal retractions, and/or expiratory grunting. While this patient has developed some symptoms of respiratory distress, this occurred in the first 2 hours after delivery. Furthermore, he was not born prematurely and thus, is unlikely to have NRDS.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's neonatal polycythemia is most likely due to intrauterine hypoxia. The hypoxic state leads to increased erythropoiesis, which boosts the production of RBCs to facilitate tissue oxygenation. At birth, newborns typically present with elevated venous hematocrit (> 65%), respiratory distress, cyanosis, apnea, poor feeding, hypoglycemia (due to increased glucose uptake by the circulating RBCs), and plethora. Further manifestations may include lethargy, irritability, jitteriness, seizures, and vomiting. Risk factors for developing neonatal polycythemia include maternal tobacco use, maternal diabetes, small or large size for gestational age, and delayed umbilical cord clamping.

Key learning point: Intrauterine hypoxia stimulates increased fetal erythropoiesis, leading to neonatal polycythemia with symptoms such as plethora, hypoglycemia, and poor feeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a common, self-resolving condition that results from excess fluid in the lungs. It classically occurs in full-term neonates born by cesarean delivery and resolves within 4 hours. This patient was not born by cesarean delivery, and transient tachypnea of the newborn would not explain his laboratory abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Neonatal hyperinsulinism is a possible complication in infants born to mothers with diabetes. Exposure to maternal hyperglycemia causes excess insulin production by the fetal pancreas. Neonatal hyperinsulinism can cause hypoglycemia, which may manifest with jitteriness, poor feeding, respiratory distress, and neonatal polycythemia. However, this patient's mother does not have a history of diabetes mellitus, making hyperinsulinism unlikely. This newborn's hypoglycemia is likely due to polycythemia (from increased glucose uptake by circulating RBCs), which is caused by a different condition.

E) INCORRECT:

While infants of diabetic mothers may have cardiac abnormalities, this patient has no murmur to suggest congenital heart disease. Additionally, while cyanotic heart defects may cause symptoms of respiratory distress in the newborn, it would be less likely to explain this patient's laboratory abnormalities.
questions.hint: This newborn's elevated venous hematocrit (> 65%) indicates neonatal polycythemia.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-year history of fatigue, increased sweating, and itching in his legs. Vital signs are normal. He is 175 cm tall and weighs 116 kg; BMI is 38. On examination, he has facial flushing and bluish discoloration of the lips. Abdominal examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Red blood cell (RBC) count, blood

6.9 × 1012/L (4.00–5.50)


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
200 g/L (125–170)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood

13.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood

540 × 109/L (130–380)


Ferritin, blood
8 μg/L (24–336)


Iron, blood
8.6 μmol/L (12–31)


Iron-binding capacity, total (TIBC), blood
71.6 μmol/L (45–81)


Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

PV is an incurable disease; the primary goal of treatment is to reduce RBC mass and thus the risk of thrombotic complications. First-line treatment of PV consists of periodic phlebotomy, which reduces cell counts and hyperviscosity. In addition, antiplatelet prophylaxis with aspirin should be administered unless contraindications are present because platelets have a significantly shorter lifespan and regeneration period and are therefore less affected by phlebotomy. If first-line treatment is ineffective or poorly tolerated, or if the patient has a high risk of thrombosis (e.g., > 60 years of age, history of thrombosis), cytoreductive therapy with hydroxyurea or interferon alpha is recommended. Ruxolitinib is used for patients resistant or intolerant to hydroxyurea.

Diagnosis of PV can be established if a patient meets all three major diagnostic criteria (i.e., evidence of increased RBCs, bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth, and evidence of a JAK2 gene mutation) or the first two major criteria and the minor criterion (i.e., decreased EPO levels).

Key learning point: The initial treatment for polycythemia vera is periodic phlebotomy to reduce red blood cell mass and decrease the risk of thrombotic complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is the first-line treatment for sickle cell disease. Hydroxyurea can also be used as an adjunct cytoreductive treatment for PV in patients with a high risk for thrombosis (e.g., > 60 years of age, history of thrombosis) or for whom first-line treatment of PV is ineffective or poorly tolerated. None of these indications are observed in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Weight loss can be beneficial for various conditions including obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OSA may cause obesity, tiredness, and increased RBC count due to elevated EPO secretion (secondary to chronic hypoxia). However, a history of restless sleep and irregular snoring with apneic episodes would be expected in patients with OSA. Also, increased EPO levels would not explain this patient's leukocytosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation is the treatment of choice in individuals with iron deficiency anemia. Patients typically present with fatigue, decreased serum ferritin and serum iron, as well as elevated or high-normal total iron binding capacity. However, iron deficiency typically leads to microcytic anemia (hypochromic) and decreased hemoglobin, which are absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitor imatinib is the first-line treatment in leukemias associated with Philadelphia translocation, which includes > 90% of cases of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Common features of CML include fatigue, increased sweating, and leukocytosis. Pruritus and plethora are not typical of CML. Also, affected individuals often have a much higher leukocyte count compared to this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with constitutional symptoms (fatigue, sweating), pruritus, and plethora (i.e., facial flushing and cyanotic lips). In combination with an increase of all three blood cell lines (i.e., erythrocytosis, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis), these findings suggest polycythemia vera (PV). In patients with PV, low serum iron and serum ferritin, as well as high-normal total iron-binding capacity indicate increased incorporation of iron into hemoglobin due to excessive hematopoiesis and hemoglobin production.

questions.text: You are seeing a 53-year-old woman in the emergency department who presents with blurry vision, headache, and multiple episodes of nosebleeds over the past few weeks. She also reports significant itching, an 8-kg weight loss, and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. Her blood pressure is 158/90 mm Hg. On examination, there are no lesions or evidence of trauma in the nasal cavity. Her face, palms, nail beds, oral mucosa, and conjunctiva are red. Abdominal examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin concentration of 190 g/L (115–155), hematocrit of 0.58 (0.38–0.50), platelets of 450 × 109/L (130–380), and a below-normal erythropoietin level. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An EPO receptor mutation is a typical finding in individuals with primary familial and congenital polycythemia (PFCP). PFCP is a rare disorder that may manifest with findings similar to those seen in PV, including highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), low EPO levels, plethora, fatigue, headache, hypertension, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, a patient with PFCP would typically have a normal-sized spleen, earlier onset of symptoms, and a family history positive for this condition. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical findings of PFCP, such as a normal platelet count, which indicates that other hematopoietic cell lines are not involved (isolated erythrocytosis).

B) CORRECT:

A mutation in the Janus kinase 2 gene (JAK2 gene) is an important etiological factor in a number of myeloproliferative neoplasms. The mutation is present in almost all cases of PV and in ∼ 50% of patients with essential thrombocythemia and primary myelofibrosis. For the diagnosis of PV to be established, all three major criteria or the minor criterion plus two major criteria must be fulfilled. The major criteria are evidence of increased RBCs (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth, and genetic analysis showing a mutation in the JAK2 gene. The minor criterion is decreased EPO levels.

Key learning point: Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative neoplasm most commonly caused by a JAK2 gene mutation, leading to increased red blood cell mass and low erythropoietin levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can cause paraneoplastic syndrome, in which increased EPO production results in an inappropriate absolute polycythemia. Individuals with RCC may present with findings similar to those seen in this patient, including elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), elevated platelet count, weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome, pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, and plethora. However, this patient presents with low EPO levels, making paraneoplastic syndrome unlikely. Moreover, she lacks other typical features of RCC, including hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass.

D) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of predominantly megakaryocyte lineage is a typical finding in patients with essential thrombocythemia (ET). This patient has some features of ET, including elevated platelet count, mucosal bleeding, headache, visual disturbances, weight loss, and fatigue. However, ET would not explain her highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct) and plethora. Moreover, in patients with ET, pruritus that is exacerbated by presumably hot water is relatively uncommon, occurring in less than 5% of cases.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), including hypertension with facial flushing, mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes. However, increased ICP would not explain this patient's highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb, ↑ Hct), pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, or weight loss.
questions.hint: This patient has a highly elevated RBC mass (↑ Hb and ↑ Hct), low EPO levels, and thrombocytosis along with constitutional symptoms (weight loss, fatigue), hyperviscosity syndrome (triad of mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes), pruritus (likely exacerbated by hot water when getting ready for work), hypertension, splenomegaly, and plethora. These are features of polycythemia vera (PV).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ED with severe headache, blurred vision, and lightheadedness. He reports generalized itching after hot showers for several months. His face appears flushed. Neurological examination is normal, but abdominal examination reveals mild splenomegaly. Vital signs are temperature 36.9 °C (98.4 °F), blood pressure 158/92 mmHg, heart rate 84 beats/min, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 20.1 g/dL, hematocrit 62%, white blood cell count 13,400/mm3, and platelets 720 × 109/mm3. CT head is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate therapy?

choices.text: Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide can be used for idiopathic intracranial hypertension or altitude sickness, which may present with headache, but it is not appropriate for polycythemia vera. It does not reduce thrombotic risk, and its diuretic effect could worsen hemoconcentration.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is indicated only for confirmed thrombosis. This patient has hyperviscosity symptoms but no documented clot, so the priority is to lower hematocrit with phlebotomy rather than starting heparin.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea is used as cytoreductive therapy for chronic control of polycythemia vera, especially in high-risk patients, but it acts over weeks and is not appropriate as emergency treatment for acute hyperviscosity symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient’s hyperviscosity symptoms (headache, visual changes), aquagenic pruritus, splenomegaly, markedly elevated hematocrit, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis are classic for polycythemia vera. The immediate ED priority is to reduce blood viscosity and thrombotic risk by performing urgent phlebotomy, alongside hydration and hematology referral.

E) INCORRECT:

Dual antiplatelet therapy is used for secondary prevention after acute arterial events such as myocardial infarction or ischemic stroke. It is not appropriate for polycythemia vera without a confirmed thrombosis and would not relieve acute hyperviscosity. It also increases bleeding risk, which is already elevated in PV due to abnormal platelet function.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of blurry vision and fatigue for 2 months. During this period, he has also had occasional bleeding from his gums after brushing his teeth. One month ago, he was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis after returning from an overseas business meeting. His pulse is 118/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 149/91 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips. There is hepatosplenomegaly. Sensory examination of the hands shows paresthesia. Hemoglobin concentration is 18 g/dL, hematocrit is 65%, leukocytes are 15,000/μL, and platelets are 470,000/μL. His serum erythropoietin concentration is decreased. Activation of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) due to a gain-of-function mutation can lead to the development of several types of cancers. Examples of proto-oncogenes encoding for RTKs include ERBB2 (associated with breast and gastric carcinomas), RET (associated with MEN 2A, MEN 2B, and papillary thyroid carcinoma), and ALK gene (associated with lung adenocarcinoma). However, the mutated gene responsible for polycythemia vera does not encode for a receptor tyrosine kinase.

B) INCORRECT:

Activation of a cytokine receptor due to a gain-of-function mutation in the proto-oncogene c-KIT is associated with the development of several types of cancers, including gastrointestinal stromal tumors, acute myeloid leukemia, and melanomas. However, the mutated gene responsible for polycythemia vera does not encode for a cytokine receptor.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of transcription factors due to a gain-of-function mutation can lead to the development of several types of cancers. Examples of proto-oncogenes encoding for transcription factors include c-myc (associated with Burkitt lymphoma), MYCL1 (associated with lung tumor), and N-myc (associated with neuroblastoma). However, the mutated gene responsible for polycythemia vera does not encode for a transcription factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Activation of an antiapoptotic molecule due to a gain-of-function mutation in the proto-oncogene BCL-2 is associated with the development of follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B cell lymphoma. However, the mutated gene responsible for polycythemia vera does not encode for an antiapoptotic molecule.

E) CORRECT:

A vast majority of patients with polycythemia vera (PV) have a gain-of-function (activating) mutation in the JAK2 gene, which encodes for the oncogenic nonreceptor tyrosine kinase JAK2. This JAK2V617F mutation causes an EPO-independent proliferation of the myeloid cell lines that leads to pancytosis. Associated symptoms include hyperviscosity syndrome (mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes), thrombotic events (e.g, deep vein thrombosis), cyanotic lips, hypertension, and splenomegaly, all of which are seen in this patient. Renal EPO production is suppressed in PV due to negative feedback mechanisms. The JAK2V617F mutation can also be found in over 50 % of patients with essential thrombocythemia or primary myelofibrosis.

Another oncogenic nonreceptor tyrosine kinase is BCR-ABL (associated with CML and ALL).

F) INCORRECT:

Activation of a serine/threonine kinase (STK) due to a gain-of-function mutation in the proto-oncogene BRAF is associated with the development of several types of cancer including melanoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, papillary thyroid carcinoma, and hairy cell leukemia. However, the mutated gene responsible for polycythemia vera does not encode for a STK.
questions.hint: Pancytosis (erythrocytosis, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis) in combination with decreased erythropoietin (EPO) concentration raises suspicion for polycythemia vera.
